questions.question_text:
A network administrator discovers several unknown files in the root directory of his Linux FTP server. One of the files is a tarball, two are shell script files, and the third is a binary file is named "nc." The FTP server's access logs show that the anonymous user account logged in to the server, uploaded the files, and extracted the contents of the tarball and ran the script using a function provided by the FTP server's software. The ps command shows that the nc file is running as process, and the netstat command shows the nc process is listening on a network port.
What kind of vulnerability must be present to make this remote attack possible?
questions.answer_description:
To upload files the user must have proper write file permissions.
References: http://codex.wordpress.org/Hardening_WordPress

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Not B because it says the the activities were done by the 'anonymous user account' which logged in to the server.

Selected Answer: A
File system permission is required to be able to run a script inside the folder
File System Permission, it is the weakness that allowed adversary to copy malicious file also allowed to execute it.
Ftp users donâ€™t have permissions to start processes. Privelige escalation is needed to achieve this
File system permissions is correct
To upload files user needs file permissions
A. file permission
Privilege Escalation

questions.question_text: A company's security policy states that all Web browsers must automatically delete their HTTP browser cookies upon terminating. What sort of security breach is this policy attempting to mitigate?

discussion.content: Definitely not D. Answer is A.

Had my 312-50 today, I looked for the questions that were in the exam and found this website, all the question from here appeared in the exam.
I wish I could find this site before taking the exam :/
Correct answer is D

choices.B: Attempts by attackers to access the user and password information stored in the company's SQL database.
choices.D: Attempts by attackers to determine the user's Web browser usage patterns, including when sites were visited and for how long.
choices.C: Attempts by attackers to access passwords stored on the user's computer without the user's knowledge.
choices.A: Attempts by attackers to access Web sites that trust the Web browser user by stealing the user's authentication credentials.

questions.answer_description:
Cookies can store passwords and form content a user has previously entered, such as a credit card number or an address.
Cookies can be stolen using a technique called cross-site scripting. This occurs when an attacker takes advantage of a website that allows its users to post unfiltered HTML and JavaScript content.
References: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_cookie#Cross-site_scripting_.E2.80.93_cookie_theft

As a matter of good practice any PII should be protected with strong encryption.
References: https://cuit.columbia.edu/cuit/it-security-practices/handling-personally-identifying-information
questions.question_text: Which of the following is considered the best way to protect Personally Identifiable Information (PII) from Web application vulnerabilities?

choices.A: Use cryptographic storage to store all PII
choices.C: Use full disk encryption on all hard drives to protect PII
choices.D: Use a security token to log into all Web applications that use PII
choices.B: Use encrypted communications protocols to transmit PII

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
If you want to protect PII on a Web Application that generally means the data will be in transit so storage wouldn't be the correct answer.
I think B is the correct answer
Bad question. If my website is vulnerable (OWASP: sql injection, csrf, or parameter tampering) none of the answers help..

A. Justification: Cryptography is Encryption. Storing is any time the data is in any type of memory. B -> A but A is more comprehensive and would cover transmission memory, servers, hard disks etc. It is a more comprehensive answer.
For Me A snd B is the answer but now which is the most correct?.. as they asked for web application and not storage, I will pick B. storage is not done on web application level but on DB/server level
Also for me is B. We are talking about web services and here ecrypted communications are the most important.
I think it is B also.

Use encrypted communications protocols to transmit PII. Even According to your comment, the right answer is B. I don't know the reason why a lot of website is choosing cryptographic storage. If you choose A as your answer can you give the reason because it has become the bone of contention. Thanks. If there is no reason then B. is the right answer.

questions.question_text: The security concept of "separation of duties" is most similar to the operation of which type of security device?
questions.answer_description:
In most enterprises the engineer making a firewall change is also the one reviewing the firewall metrics for unauthorized changes. What if the firewall administrator wanted to hide something? How would anyone ever find out? This is where the separation of duties comes in to focus on the responsibilities of tasks within security.
References: http://searchsecurity.techtarget.com/tip/Modern-security-management-strategy-requires-security-separation-of-duties

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
As for me it is a bastion host - as a server especially hardened with only one responsibility.
